title: Geoff's Y-Axis Idler Pulley & Gear for Solidoodle2 - all 3D printed

description.text:
This is my (hopefully improved) Y-Axis Idler Pulley & Gear for Solidoodle2. It's all 3D printed, the only extra parts are the 2 ball bearings and a piece of 2.5mm carbon fiber (or steel) to strengthen the (fully printed) toothed belt pulley. It's the absolute minimum size needed to do the job properly, and my Print Head carriage doesn't crash into the Y-idler bearing assembly anymore, plus it's really quiet and should never wear out. Also, the inside is curved, so the toothed belt just slides in when everything is fully assembled The only extra mod is to drill out the (IMHO very stupidly designed) screw mount to 3mm, so the screw is attached from the outside, a great improvement if one isn't triple jointed :-) Ball bearing details
bearingDia = 13 ; // bearing Dia (mm)
bearingWd = 5 ; // actual width of bearing (mm)
bearingIn = 4 ; // inside dia of bearing (mm)

Blue Legion markers for the classic board game.  Base is 2 mm, pic is 0.6 mm.

I imported these using Cura from a gif I found on the net (0.6 height, 2 mm base, 25 mm square, no filtering).  I sliced in Cura (which does better with fine detail than most other slicers) and then edited the gcode to switch extruders from blue to white at the 2mm mark.  This should be an easy task for a slicer, but I haven't found a slicer that does it right straight off.  Same thing could be achieved with a pause for filament switch on a single-extruder machine.  
I'm using a Felix, so write me if you also have one and I can send you the gcode.  
Will upload the markers for the other 5 colors when I get a chance.

title: Viking Warband Part 1 (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Well, the Wayfarer Tactics Kickstarter campaign is moving right along tanks to our amazing backers! We've met our goal, but we've got a few more days to make even more books and models, so be sure and check in and drop us a pledge! "From the far shore they hail, white sails flying in the mist-bound winds. By the dragon headed prow shall you know these invaders, these cold men born of the dragon and the wolf. Gather your iron, for they come to take what is yours by blood and by fire." Wayfarer Tactics is a dynamic miniature wargaming system. With these rules, you can use models from your collection to enact skirmishes, large-scale battles, or party-centered dungeon crawls. Based loosely on our Wayfarer multiverse setting, you can stage your battles in worlds of magic-rich high fantasy, far-flung intergalactic scifi, or anything in between. Check out our Kickstarter Video! In addition, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Wayfarer Tactics. Check it out here. Enjoy!

description.text:
This is one of the coolest dummy UAvs the military had used throughout history.  
This is perfect as a mock scale item on military scale RC aircraft.

I have confirmed that there is no such item available from either 80/20, nor Faztech (compatible) for joining parallel extrusions. You could use a butt-joiner, but that is not as ideal for these "parallel" scenarios. I actually need this for joining long 1530 and 40-4096 pieces together. This works with any 15 or 40 series extrusions great!  
I also created a hidden bottom/inside 90 degree corner adapter to complement the existing 2 bolt top/inside 90 degree corner adapter (they don't make one like this).  
I printed these with ABS at 50% infill and they fit perfectly, which is to say snugly, may need to tap a little with a mallet to make slide in some pieces, but no breakage.
I made this in 1 minute on Tinkercad. Fun!
Um, go make your own on Tinkercad! Don't put my name on your door, do it your own way with your own name!

title: Replacement Belt Clip for Phone Holster

description.text: We have purchased several phone holsters for our two Samsung Galaxy S3 phones because this part keeps breaking. We have tried different brands, and they all suffer from the same weakness. Now I can just print a new one when it breaks next time. The pin holes are less prone to breaking because they are wider, but this also means that you have to push the pin in a little deeper to get the fully effective hold. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/6szHBRhzYjY

** Update 6/13/13
First version seems to have had some issues with its tinkercad export, but tinkercad is down for 'updating'. I will post an updated stl as soon as it is back up and I can make some modifications. ** Update 6/13/13
Updated .stl uploaded. ** Update 9/19/13
Uploaded V2 that should fit much better.

A very simple device to hold your filament spool : drill an 8mm hole in one of your SmartrapCore's wall, insert a M8 x 100 bolt, put the 608ZZ bearings inside the printed parts (it's the exact same piece on both sides, just print it twice), hold the whole thing with washers and nuts, and lets roll (and not rock), baby! :)
The cone shape should adjust to most spools sizes. I use it at home with a 75mm wide spool (60mm diameter central hole) and it works really fine. Update (10/15/2015) : added an axis support that can be easily installed on the top of the box. This way, you won't have to drill a hole in the printer's box, and then you can also put this spool holder wherever you want on the box (it's completely symetrical, so it can go on the other side, you don't need to print another one), which can be pretty useful if you want to try dual extrusion (like with my twin head support : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:995640 ;)). Update (03/02/2016) : simply added the zipped Blender source file, so if you want to adapt or modify this device it'll be easier. ;) Update (06/25/2017) : added two spacers to avoid using M8 nuts.

comments.text: I just realized that the axis support (the part thats installed on top of the box) can't be used on sides of the box because it'll hit the Y carriage parts. You can only put it behind the printer, but I have my electronics there... So I guess I gotta drill hole on the side or think of something else!
comments.author: WhiteRenard

comments.text:
The axis support I made is actually designed to fit a standard working wooden box SmartrapCore. There's not much space between the Y carriage and the spool axis support but if the dimensions and design are correct it's supposed to work fine.
So no, it's not supposed to be installed behind the printer
I'll make and show some pictures of the actual spool holder that's installed on my SmartrapCore (I even have two of them, one of each side, as I use them with my new dual extrusion design), as soon as I can find time for that.

author: Bribro12

description.text: Complete mini 3D printer with Arduino core - Mini Replicator Prusa I3 based 3D printer This contains all the files to print your own 3D Printer. You only have to buy the rest of the parts. Arduino or atmega 2560 R3, nema 17 steppers, end switches belts and pulley's and 6 mm axles and bearings and of course a hot-end J-head E3D a more precise list you can find on www.3dtje.nl In my opinion each 3D printer should be reproducing at least one sister or brother printer, in this case I developed a complete 3D printed printer. This printer is used in 3D printerworkshops at the Stockholms school of Economics and at the TKH stockholm (technical university) If you build this printer, please consider donating a second printer to a local school or a youngster who is really into 3d printing and technique. Let's put smiles on those faces ;-)) 27-feb-2016: One of the 3Dtjes is now at the milton peeters college st maarten. It's been donated by me to the IT class. Their first assignement was to print a new printer (Prusa I3) and give the old or new to the next school on the island.

18-nov-2015:
  • There was a second problem reported with the file for the bowdenmount part b. i've checkted the drwaing and made some ajustments. I use Slic3r te produce the gcode. a new file is uploaded.
  • There was a mistake with the filename for the firmware. I,ve uploaded a new file, if you encounter any problems please let me know.
  • Added optional part. This Replicator 1 Spool Holder is quite compact and has perfect dimensions to fit on the back of the 3Dtje printer. It also provides an excellent mounting point for a display-rest. When installed the carrying handle rests on this part and subsequently the display rests on the handle in a perfect angle. Update 16-jun-2016: For wider spools this remix was made, combining a display-rest and an enlarged 10cm long spoolholder. Unfortunately that version requires a larger sized printbed than the mini printer 3Dtje has.
    • 12-mar-2016:
  • Replaced the feeder with a new file. this adjustment makes it easier to fill the filament. the hole for the connector is a bit bigger to fit a M5 insert.
    • 16-jun-2016:
  • Replaced lower Z-axis supports left and right. (Fix for updated distance between baseplate mounting holes, 31mm instead of 30mm).
  • Added new version of baseplate with higher mountpoint for feeder to allow easier manual feed of filament. Note that the latest feeder is mounted with the lever at the bottom and its end on the inside. The bowden tube is attached to the fixed part, not to the lever. This way the filament goes straight up into the bowden tube.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,3 mm

Infill:

40-50%

Notes: I'v been printing this on a 0,4 nozzle and 0,3 mm layer, but if you use a smaller nozzle you have to adjust the layer.

This printer is build with PLA, whenever i've time I put some instructive video's on Youtube. There are only a few parts used so basically just print them and you should see how to fit them together. All of the holes are on their place and I used M3 screws in various lengths. The Z-axis is an M5 threaded rod. I've glued a small mirror on the printbed using double sided tape to obtain a perfectly flat surface. You also need to download the arduino program to burn the firmware on the atmega board. Visit my website for more info or simply post here or send an email in case you question is ignored.

comments.text:
Happy new year and congratulations! You've made great progress! On the occasions I saw banding it seemed related to bends in the threaded rods. If I compare your build with my printer and others, the main difference seems that your rods are protruding the top. As these rods are plain screws, not made of hardened steel, they will bend easier. In my printer they are cut off just below the holes. I can imagine protruding the top may cause extra tension in the rods. If you have some shorter spares, give those a try and compare the results (of course without changing any settings or using different filament).
There may be other causes though, such as a loose belt, steppers skipping steps, irregular extrusion, etc.. You may need to print some other models for comparison. I found this guide very helpful in resolving common printing problems.
Good luck!
comments.author: fiveseven808

comments.text: Thank you! I believe you're right with the bending in the threaded rods. When my Z axis does a G0 fast move (and it moves quite fast lol) the whole printer shakes. Something was out of alignment or loose but I figured that the Z axis moves so slowly when printing, the belt tension would keep things tight when printing at a low speed. It makes sense that bent threaded rods would cause the wobble even at low speeds, and introduce banding during prints. I'll check on that tonight.

comments.text: Hello, Good to read you like this printer! I also like it very much and often use it for various purposes. I know the maker and let me tell you about the origin of this printer. It is in fact the result of a bet between myself and the maker. I participated in a Kickstarter for an affordable mini-printer, but they had problems producing it. After waiting for more than a year without receiving that printer, the maker said she could make me one. I replied: that's great, but I need it to be just as small and affordable. She accepted that challenge and the 3Dtje printer is the result. When months later the Kickstarter printer eventually showed up, it looked nice, but was not great at printing. Both the software and firmware were buggy and the quality of the hardware wasn't good either. Cheap stepper motors caused wobbly inaccurate prints. In contrast the 3Dtje printer delivered high quality prints as it used the same software and hardware as the Prusa I3. In fact, I never used my Kickstarter printer anymore and it's been gathering dust ever since.

comments.text: How does the belt on the bed attach
comments.author: andy93211

comments.text: It attaches using the same technique as used on the x-axis. Both ends of the belt meet each other at the bottom of the bed (or backside of the extruder mount). There you find slots for each end. By folding the belt-end around a pin back and interlocking to the earlier piece of belt into the slot, you create a sturdy yet adjustable attachment that cannot easily be pulled out of the slot. However, make sure that the slot is cleaned out and wide enough to fit the thickness of an interlocking piece of belt. In case the loop-pin didn't print properly (too messy or too thin), you can break it off and fill the loop of the belt-end with a piece of filament.

comments.text:
Yes, that was the mismatch. At first, I thought it was because my Z axis E-steps were incorrect (from the factory), but even I recalibrated the holes didn't seem to line up correctly.
I've gotten so used to press fitting 3d printed parts, I didn't even think about drilling out the holes.
So far I haven't found any other issues, but I'm only part way through the assembly process.
comments.author: 3Dtje

comments.text:
I've noticed a few issues with the design of some parts (several screw holes that should go through the entire part do not, some parts could be modified to reduce required support material,)
Have you considered releasing the source files to allow for editing? I would be willing to share any improvements that I create if you do not object to it.
Edit: I was test fitting some of the parts that I printed out, and it appears that there are several places where holes do not line up properly (particularly on the Z motor mounts and the standing plate)
I'm assuming that the holes were moved in a new version of one of the parts, but that change was not made in the part it interfaces with.

description.text: bottle holder for 0.5lt, 1lt & 1,5lt bottle. You can attach a carabiner and hang on the backpack. you can use that for the mark your bottle in gym.

Golf fans will value this...  
The 'Rotating Golf Ball Key Fob' is approx. the same diameter as a regular golf ball but slim (only 5mm thick) so it fits easily onto your key ring... not a 'ball in your pocket.   
The ball features dimples of a similar size as a regular golf ball and the centre (ball) section is independent of the outer ring so it rotates freely. This is a simple one piece print comprised of two parts that rotate around each other.  
i recommend printing at the current scale to maintain the clearances designed in (so it rotates freely) and make the ball a close representation of a dimpled golf ball size wise.  
After printing remove the raft (if used) then gently wiggle to free inner part until it starts rotating freely. With most good (accurate) machines the centre should free quickly and easily making it a spinning ball inside the slimline outer ring.   
The file is quite large due to the detail in the dimples on the ball surface... but well worth the download. If you're a golfer you will appreciate this, if not. but you know a golfer, print one as a gift.   
Refer to instructions for print setting recommendations.   
Note: If you like this check out all my other designs.

Recommended settings (... these work well on a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicator) Raft On
Standard / 0.20mm resolution
75% infill (to make it almost solid / strong)
No Support After printing remove the raft (if used) then gently wiggle to free inner part until it starts rotating freely. With most good (accurate) machines the centre should free quickly and easily making it a spinning ball inside the slim line outer ring. The file is quite large due to the detail in the dimples on the ball surface... but well worth the download.
Pokemon first gen

these hinges are stronger then comercial hinges for rc models if printed on the right settings ,i printed these with pla on a temperture of about 210 degrees .i use this hinges on a 3 meter span wing of a cessna 182 rc model .i use 3 sets of hinges (1 dubbel, one single ) for one flap .
hope you like it

description.text: Scanned with ReconstructMe and an Xbox Kinect at the Coney Island Scan-A-Rama booth at Danbury Makerfaire on Saturday June 8, 2013. It was the public debut of my new scanning rig- the Scan-O-Tron 3000, and the scans have been beautiful. I am about to kick off a Kickstarter for Scan-A-Rama and plan to open source my plans, so stay tuned. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is a next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio will be appearing at MakerFaires and in Coney Island throughout 2013. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama I recommend printing at .27 or .1 mm layer height with no support. You may have to trim a couple bits of hanging plastic off, but this will look great with no support.

author: JohnAssmundsson

description.text:
I was searching for something to easy help me with the filament material settings. Nothing big or with long waiting times. For that a long list of things is available, but just for trying the most important settings as temperatures, flows, speed, layer height, etc. Here is it: print time is only 5-10 minutes, depends on your settings and it helps a lot:
  • all measures in millimeters
  • walls are exact 1.0mm to see eventual over- or underflow
  • a little 45° overhang with a 1.0mm platform that shows warping and if you probably need to change the filament-fan speed
  • stringging in the tube or between tube and platform
  • a 0.2mm space between the cube and the cylinder to check with a paper if needed
    • On the picture are some printed examples. Nylon, T-Glase and Flex in the first row (from left to right), different ABS, PLA and XT filaments in the back. Hope that this little thing is help you in the same way it is helping me with every new material! Tip: Double the size in the slicer to 200% to get an even better impression at the end of the settings! (see the two pictures at the end). Enjoy! See also my thing to check easy for overhangs and general filament settings: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2611846 Problems with layer bonding or need some layer calibrations? Check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2182560

author: jbs

description.text:
Replace of the ´blue horse shoe´ that comes with the Ultimaker Kit.  
This design takes the play out of the Bodwen tube, reducing retraction and underextrusion issues.  
This version is a variation of the ´Ultimaker retraction ring´ made by JelleBoomstra, being smaller, wich allows to rotate it easily, making possible to attach it to the Hotend´s Bowden tube without problems because will not touch the cables (cartridge heater, PT 100, and fan).

To Print:
0.1 layer height
100% infill When printed:
1- Remove the ´blue horse shoe´ (or whatever you have)
2- Insert bowden tube into clamp until goes down no more
3- Insert the ´new Clip´
4- Print happily!

title: OverLord Belt & Motor Protector - Snap-On Design

description.text:
The back pillar, belt and all around the heating plate looks messy on my OverLord Pro. Hairspray, glue leavings, small parts, strings, and every dirt from the built plate is typically falling down here. Wondering that no plastic is blocking the motor pulley!  
This protector is easily clipping on the three stilts. Designed that motor waste heat is not blocked. Snap it just on!   
Rods to not crash with these parts also if you print diameters of 172mm on our printer. The piece needs only 1.5-2.0mm. Tested, see pictures!   
Printed mine in 1h15' with Taulman T-Glase (see instructions) but any other material is suitable. Enjoy!

title: Click&Fix; Filament Spool Bearing Railway - Flexible positioning, for any common spools, works for any length

description.text: Spool roller systems I have seen need to be adjusted with screws, since every roll is different. This system is easy clickable as the bearing holders are pushed by hand on the common 8mm threaded bars. This is made by a little bit more than a half inside thread in the pieces. The complete construction is very space efficient: in height as well in the width as the spools can be placed very narrow to the edges (see pictures). Since every printer has different tolerances I made three different diameters: Try first 'Spool Guide No2'. If it is to strong on the thread bar, use the No3 with more diameter. If it is not keeping in place, use the No1 with closer tolerances. Would be very nice if you could give a feedback which number is best fitting for you! And probably some pictures! Thanks! Making is easy: print as many as of the spool guides you need and two of the 'Guide Basis' to mount at the place you like to install them (filament dry box, a good example from bummster: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961881, shelf board, etc.) You don't need nuts or washers for mounting the bearings, all this is built into the part and the screw will be countersunk on one side and clamp on the other. See instructions for more info. Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.3 layer height

Infill:

75 - 100%

Notes: I made it in PLA (pictures) and ABS.
Print times: 2x Spool Guide = 40', 2x Guide Basis = 60'
SketchUp, the M8 inside thread was a bit tricky to combine with the model.

All parts are printed in PLA with 0.2mm layer height. You need:
  • 2x 8mm threaded bars in your length
  • 8x M8 nuts with washers to mount the bars
  • 4x 625 (5x16x5mm) or 688* (8x16x5mm) bearings for each spool
  • 4x M5x16 countersunk screws for each spool
  • 4x M5x25 countersunk screws (depends on your situation) to mount all in a box or at the place
    • *The 625 bearings are very common and fit without any additional part. The 688 bearings I used are also used often, but you can use other bearings with a width of 5mm. If the outer diameter is bigger than 16mm you probably need to underlay the construction at the installing place. The inner diameter of my 688 bearings is attached to the M5 screw by little bearing inlays (see attached files). The 'Guide Basis' is to mount your construction into a box or somewhere. If your threaded bars are not stable enough with the two mounting parts you can use 'Guide Half Basis' to support them in the middle (see pictures). Keep in mind that the mounting parts have not to be at the ends of the threaded bars, in this way you save space and can place the spools very narrow to the edges of your available space.

title: Small Test Whislte done in OpenSCAD

description.text:
I designed a small whistle as a starting point for a playable ocarina. My plan is to make something that sounds decent as a closed vessel, then drill finger holes starting with the lowest notes. If all goes well and I can get it tuned, I'll measure the holes and add them to the model. Starting with a 2cm cube I added rounded corners with the built in minkowski function and then added "mouthpiece" using a fillet function I found here:
https://github.com/clothbot/ClothBotCreations/blob/master/utilities/fillet.scad Next I hollowed it out and added a fipple using the technique of TLAR (that looks about right) and was a bit surprised that it actually played a note (sort of). Some adjustments may be needed here... Eventually I'll make it a bit larger, this was just a quick test print. I'm also trying out some different print orientations. I put it 45deg on edge because that first layer is usually pretty ugly and PLA printers seems to handle that much overhand fine without support. I've also included the STL w/o support in case you'd like to do that yourself. Thanks for looking!
Bob M Update: multiple changes to the .scad file. See github for a complete history: https://github.com/bobm123/maker I rendered a larger one with interior volume of about 65 x 45 x 25 mm and included a couple of .stl with support options I was playing with. According to my chromatic tuner, print plays a slightly flat C#. Next I'll see if I can make it into an ocarina.

I did my first print from the STL file with support, slices set for .25mm layer height, 15% fill. My print time was about 45 min.  
Same print settings used for the larger version oriented on its side. Print time was about 2 1/2 hours.  
To generate a whistle at a different size, open whistle.scad and modify the length, width and height parameters. You can also try one of my two attempts at generating support by removing comments at line 23, 24 or 25. If you go for the unsupported version, you'll probably have to add some with your slicer. I gave up with the auto generated supports as they kept messing up the interior. That's why the other two versions. If you try the 90deg orientation be careful with the height or you might run into trouble making the bridges for the top of the print.

Hi InMoov builder

(InMoov is a 3D printable Robot designed by Gael Langevin (browse to InMoov.fr))

I have created a few OpenScad files that will allow to produce individual versions of parts that connect to servos.

Don't expect it to be perfect (its version 1) and drop me a note if you are not happy with the result or need another one.

Juerg

You need to download and install OpenScad (open source) to open the .SCAD file.
Look at the top of the script (Use View/Enable Editor if you can not see the script) and provide your servo's values.
View the thing with F5, if you are happy create an .STL by first using F6 and than Export as STL.
I strongly suggest to analyse the STL with netfabb. Check for some relevant reference points with the measuring tool and make sure it adds up with your servo before printing.
You can find instruction for creating the stl for the opposite side in the script header as well.
Have fun
Juerg + Marvin

title: Magnetic electrical connector for LGB Carriages and Trains

description.text:
This is a small magnetic coupling that can clip onto the center buffer of LGB carriages and engines. It automatically links when the train couples to the carriage, making electrical contact from one carriage to another possible.
I have used this to couple power from the engine to light the carriages without having to have track brushes on the carriage wheels.

First drill out all your "part 1" parts to 3mm to accept 3mm magnets. (or 2mm for 2mm magnets)
I used 3mm 1mm for the photographs, but plan to also try 2mm 2mm magnets later. Make one part up with a N pole up on one side and a south pole up on the other. Then superglue it to brass strip as this will be a very useful tool for making the rest of your connectors. Get 0.1inch ribbon cable and strip it to make a 2 core cable and strip the wire for aboout 8mm. Push this from the recessed side to the flat side, and then place two new magnets on the tool you have made. The tool holds these in the right place and makes sure that you have the N and S poles all the same for your trains.
Push the plastic part onto the magnets, making sure not to short the bare wires, and ensuring that the bare wires contact the magnets. Fold the wires over the bottom, and superglue the recess on the back. (see photo)
Assemble the wire first through the small hole in part 3, and then back trough the big hole and assemble part 3 onto the top of the post (part 2). The magnets should be facing outwards, with the wire fitting in the recess in the back of part 2. Adjust the height of the magnets to clear the buffer.
Click the post onto the buffer and connect the wires to your lights etc.
You can probably hide the wires better than I did in the photo!
Testing an early version I discovered that they tend to lever apart from the bottom, which is why I'm now wrapping the extra wire over the bottom of the contacts in this revised design, so it should not need the magnets to actually touch to make contact.
I have put the 123D files on here so you can modify for different magnets or make a different post to suit other carriages.
I made early versions with two 2mm0.5mm magnets but they were very difficult to fit, as the magnets tended to tilt rather than pushing in nicely. A thicker magnet is probably going to work better. The 3mm 1mm magnets in the illustrations are better and push fit nicely once you drill the hole out to 3mm, but I am planning on getting some 2mm * 2mm magnets as well and I expect that they will be easier to fit.

description.text:
Min and max end stop mount for, all three versions of
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999
http://www.vicious1.com/ Easily change your home position, stop working in the same corner. Position your material where ever you want. I printed these in PLA and they have to flex a lot to get over the rails but they seem fine after repeated tests. If you have followed this project you probably know I am against end stops. Maximums can be very useful for when you mess up your gcode, the machine will stop if it goes too far. This works on all axis for a minimum or maximum position indicators. The ramps board will accept all 6 at once. Wire it in the NO position and no firmware changes will be needed for the MPCNC.

comments.text: Picture of the switch shows that the normally open contact is used. Usually the normal closed contact is used, in case of broken wire the machine will simply not move any further since the endstop seems reached. If the no contact is used, the machine will continue to run because the input is not triggered.

author: Allted

description.text:
This is a case with lid for for a Beaglebone Black.  
This Thing uses a clearance model of the BBB to position the openings correctly.  The clearance model is provided as a separate OpenSCAD file for use in other projects.  
I've printed this in both PLA and ABS on a Makerbot Replicator.  
The lid is friction-fit.  A more positive closure would be a useful improvement.

I printed mine on a Makerbot Replicator in PLA and ABS, using Makerware with "new improved" rafts, no supports.  
The model includes a couple of explicit supports to help keep the larger openings from sagging.  Cut them away with a hobby knife after printing.  
When installing the board, push the end of the board with the microSD slot down first, aligning the two pegs with the mounting holes, then push down the other end.  
The OpenSCAD file for the box generates both the lid and the base.  I used code comments to isolate each part when generating separate STLs.  
You can set the variable 'floorThickness' to 0 to generate a box without a floor. This uses less plastic, is quicker to print, and makes it easier to remove the board.

comments.text: You should subtract lidLipThickness from r1 and r2 in boxNegative() and from lipR1 and lipR2 for the inner lip radius in the lid() module, so that the walls are the same thickness all around instead of varying in size as they go around the corner.
comments.author: jsc

comments.text: Sorry, subtract wallThickness from r1 and r2 in boxNegative() (and lidLipThickness from lipR1 and lipR2 in lid()).
comments.author: jsc

comments.text: Yep, good plan.  Thanks for tracking that down.
comments.author: jsc

https://www.dropbox.com/s/tshfyiijctgxm2b/box-nofloor%20%28fixed%29.stlhttps://www.dropbox.com/s/tshf...

After a little looking, I think I understand why these have manifold problems.  I have always previously used tiny shim adjustments to avoid coincident faces on CSG models, but have recently come to suspect that was unnecessary.  Well it is necessary; although you can print fine with OpenSCAD + Makerware, the generated STL's are not necessarily manifold and will bork Slic3r.  Lesson learned - don't be lazy and add shims always.

title: CTC DUAL TO SINGLE BLOWER MOD

description.text:
I own a CTC Dual 3d printer and do not use the second extruder for more than to do some early tests.
This second extruder and his wires only causes more vibrations and troubles when maintenance.
So i remove it and use the extra space for adding an active cooling system.
This produces great results when PLA printing (or very small parts from some materials). If you want an efective active cooling system, try it. It is clean and compact design and produces better results than any of standard radial fans systems i tested. DETAIL For BOM and assembling instructions please check: http://3dpdesigns.blogspot.com.es/p/flashforge.html Update: 24/Feb/2016.-Added step source files.

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs. You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com Thank you!

description.text:
Note: These X-ends are designed to match the lead screw nuts having triangular flanges. This design allows the body of the lead screw nut to be inserted from the bottom allowing the x-end to rest on the top of the flange. Revises the nut traps to be open to the top. Re-sized them to M4.
One trap had to be open to the back. I found that the bearings aligned better if they were pressed together and centered in the part. YMMV. For a full 3d look at the part, the .PVZ file, in the downloads, can be opened in the free app Creo View. Available for PC and iPads.

Use config for your standard structural parts.
3 perimeters, 3 top, 3 bottom. Support should not be needed.

title: Splendor game organizer with support for promo noble tiles

description.text: Splendor is a fantastic tabletop game, but the box for the game has a bit of wasted space which reduces the portability of the game. I was inspired to create this design after seeing a post where someone on reddit created a minimalist foamcore organizer for the game: https://www.reddit.com/r/boardgames/comments/2w5zgy/foam_core_minimalist_box_for_splendor/. This variant of the Splendor organizer has extra room for the promo noble tiles. The organizer cover can be easily held in place with a small box band: http://www.flyingbuffalo.com/other.htm I recommend printing the cover flipped upside down so that supports are only needed under the lettering.

With this mod, you can transform your TBS Discovery to a pro like version.
The following mod are
  • Add a brushless gimbal to your TBS discovery
  • Add a VTX and LC Filter holder
  • Add a cover for a big Ublox GPS
    • See instructions for more details

Print everything at 100% Brushless Gimbal
To build the brushless gimbal, you need to print gimbal_support.stl file and also all the files included here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:898204 You need to buy those things http://www.conrad.fr/ce/fr/product/540033/Rondelle-anti-vibratoire-coloris-noir-A-x-B-x-C-x-D-144-x-48-x-33-x-82-mm-Richco-VG-2/SHOP_AREA_27898 to hold this support with the 5mm tube of the TBS (see the prictures) You can also print the 2 files brushless_card.stl and brushless_card_top.stl if you need something to hold your brushless controller Antenna Holder
This mod came in 2 parts, one to hold your VTX vertically (tbs_vtx_antenna_holder.stl) and a base (tbs_vtx_antenna.stl). You can put a LC Filter (https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__68127__L_C_Power_Filter_1_7A.html) into the base, and cover it (lc_filter_box_top.stl) As an axis, you can use a 3*20mm screw Ublox
Finally there's a ublox cover (ublox_gps_cover.stl).

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement drip pan with the ability to store 5 K-Cup's.  Useful for those of you who wake up at the last minute and need every second to get to work on time.  
Revision:  Forgot to extrude a cut in the back.

Be sure to print with support.  The center base was not extruded all the way to the bottom plane.  This was done in an attempt to minimize warping.  
Its not necessary to print out the tray since your existing one should fit on top of the pan.

comments.text: I am not able to fit this onto the bed of my Rep2. It might fit if the spokes for the holders were shortened slightly to allow me to shift the hole print forward on the PB.

I designed this to be machined out of aluminum.
I printed it out of PLA and did a couple of test prints that way. Not sure how long it would last in PLA though. It uses a 1/4" spring (http://www.mcmaster.com/nav/enter.asp?partnum=9637K66)
It comes in a set of 5 11" lengths that you have to cut to length but it's a pretty beefy spring.
I'm sure there are some other 1/4" diameter springs that would work.

For anyone with a wooden pepper grinder you may find that over time with heavy usage the internal metal rod wears a circle in the top wood piece where the wood used to be square shaped. Once this happens the grinder is essentially unusable unless you print and press fit this piece in place.  Depending on how worn yours is you made need to drill the center out to allow this piece to press in.  You want a tight fit for proper operation and so glue isn't necessary.
